sense.name: reporters
sense.commentary: Refers collectively to the newspapermen, writers, reporters, etc., who run the media.
sense.examples: George W. Bush usually refuses to speak to the press. We'll be having a press conference tomorrow at noon. I put a "Press" tag around my neck to get past security. John was a member of the press. The Associated Press reported the results of the Indonesian elections this morning.

sense.name: urgency
sense.commentary: PRESS[+event] The quality of being insistent or pressing. Being something that demands attention or immediate notice.
sense.examples: I've been hurried by the usual press of business matters.

sense.name: news collection
sense.commentary: A general term for the collection and publication of news. Does not refer to any specific people or organizations.
sense.examples: The freedom of the press is guaranteed by the First Amendment. An unbiased press is an essential part of a healthy democracy.

sense.name: printing machine
sense.commentary: A machine used for printing a large number of documents.
sense.examples: In fourth grade I learned about the inventor of the printing press. Stop the presses! The mobsters smashed our presses before we could print the story about them.

sense.name: large crowd
sense.commentary: A tightly-packed crowd, usually of people.
sense.examples: I-95 is blocked up by a huge press of cars and trucks.

sense.name: piece of furniture
sense.commentary: A tall piece of furniture that provides space for clothing. Also called a wardrobe or an armoire.
sense.examples: John put his clothes on hangers and hung them in the press.

sense.name: machine that presses
sense.commentary: Any device that exerts pressure on something. Can be used to shape or form materials, or to keep wood from warping. Includes the weightlifting machine used to exercise shoulders and chest.
sense.examples: John bought a wine press and started his own vintage. Your brakes use a hydraulic press to put pressure on the wheels. When the shop class went home, they left their wood clamped in the presses. This morning I did three sets of one-seventy on the chest press.

sense.name: exertion of pressure
sense.commentary: PRESS[+event] The resultative noun of "to press". The act of putting pressure on something, such as a button.
sense.examples: The President can start World War III at the press of a button.
